0.title: Relations
0.description: Relations define how entities connect to each other. Archetype supports three relation types that generate foreign keys, junction tables, and proper TypeScript types.
0.headings: Relations Relation Types hasOne() hasMany() belongsToMany() Optional Relations Pivot Data with through() Example: E-commerce Schema

1.title: Protection
1.description: Control which CRUD operations require authentication per entity.
1.headings: Protection Quick Options Granular Control Generated Router Examples by Use Case Blog Posts (public read, auth write) User Profiles (fully protected) Products (public catalog, admin write) Comments (custom pattern) Accessing User in Mutations Requirements

2.title: Modes
2.description: Archetype supports two generation modes. Pick based on your backend.
2.headings: Modes Quick Comparison Full Stack Mode What you get Config example Headless Mode What you get Config example Service layer When to use which Use Full Stack when: Use Headless when:

4.title: Archetype
4.description: TL;DR: Define your data model once. Get database, validation, API, and hooks generated automatically.
4.content:
# Archetype TL;DR: Define your data model once. Get database, validation, API, and hooks generated automatically. --- ## What It Generates | You Define | You Get | |------------|---------| | | Email column + Zod validation | | | Foreign keys + joined queries | | | Public reads, auth-protected mutations | | | + columns | --- ## 30-Second Start --- ## Why Use This? Without Archetype: 1. Write Drizzle schema 2. Write Zod schema (duplicate field definitions) 3. Write tRPC router (duplicate again) 4. Write React hooks 5. Keep all 4 in sync manually With Archetype: 1. Define entity once 2. Run 3. Done --- ## Next: Getting Started typescript
// You write this
const User = defineEntity('User', {
  fields: {
    email: text().required().email(),
    name: text().required(),
  },
  protected: 'write',
})
 
// You get this
generated/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ db/schema.ts              ‚Üí Drizzle tables
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ schemas/user.ts           ‚Üí Zod validation
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ trpc/routers/user.ts      ‚Üí CRUD API
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ hooks/useUser.ts          ‚Üí React hooks
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tests/user.test.ts        ‚Üí Comprehensive tests
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/openapi.json         ‚Üí API documentation
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ seeds/user.ts             ‚Üí Sample data
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ i18n/en/user.json         ‚Üí Translation keys
 

---

## What It Generates

| You Define | You Get |
|------------|---------|
|   | Email column + Zod   validation |
|   | Foreign keys + joined queries |
|   | Public reads, auth-protected mutations |
|   columns |

---

## 30-Second Start

 bash
npx create-next-app my-app && cd my-app
npm install archetype-engine
npx archetype init --yes
npx archetype generate
npx drizzle-kit push && npm run dev
 

---

## Why Use This?

**Without Archetype:**
1. Write Drizzle schema
2. Write Zod schema (duplicate field definitions)
3. Write tRPC router (duplicate again)
4. Write React hooks
5. Keep all 4 in sync manually

**With Archetype:**
1. Define entity once
2. Run  typescript write this const User defineEntity User fields email text required email name text required protected write this generated schema Drizzle tables schemas user validation trpc routers user CRUD hooks useUser React hooks tests user test Comprehensive tests docs openapi json documentation seeds user Sample data i18n user json Translation keys bash create next install archetype engine archetype init archetype generate drizzle push
4.headings: Archetype What It Generates 30-Second Start Why Use This? Next: [Getting Started](/docs/getting-started)

5.title: Hooks
5.description: Hooks let you run custom business logic before and after CRUD operations without modifying generated code.
5.headings: Hooks Enabling Hooks Generated Files Hook Types Implementing Hooks Common Patterns Auto-assign Author Validate Stock Send Notifications Audit Logging Prevent Deletion Error Handling

6.title: Getting
6.description: Get up and running with Archetype in under 5 minutes.
6.content:
# Getting Started Get up and running with Archetype in under 5 minutes. ## Prerequisites - Node.js 18+ - A Next.js project (or create one) ## Installation ### Option 1: New Project ### Option 2: Existing Project ### Option 3: Local Development (npm link) To use an unpublished local version: ## CLI Commands | Command | Description | |---------|-------------| | | Create config, entities folder, and infrastructure | | | Quick setup with SQLite defaults | | | Setup without database (for edge/serverless) | | | Generate code from | | | Generate code from JSON manifest | | | Validate JSON manifest before generating | | | Open ERD diagram in browser | See JSON Manifest for the AI-optimized workflow using a single JSON file. ## Project Structure After initialization, your project will have: ## Configuration The file is your main configuration: ### Database Options ## Next Steps - Define entities - Learn the entity API - Add fields - Text, number, boolean, date fields - Set up relations - hasOne, hasMany, belongsToMany - Enable authentication - Protect your API bash
# Create Next.js project
npx create-next-app my-app
cd my-app

# Install archetype
npm install archetype-engine

# Initialize (creates config + entities + infrastructure)
npx archetype init --yes

# Generate code
npx archetype generate

# Push database schema and run
npx drizzle-kit push
npm run dev
 

### Option 2: Existing Project

 bash
npm install archetype-engine
npx archetype init
npx archetype generate
 

### Option 3: Local Development (npm link)

To use an unpublished local version:

 bash
# In archetype-engine directory
npm run build && npm link

# In your project
npm link archetype-engine
npx archetype init
npx archetype generate
 

## CLI Commands

| Command | Description |
|---------|-------------|
|   | Create config, entities folder, and infrastructure |
|   | Quick setup with SQLite defaults |
|   | Setup without database (for edge/serverless) |
|   | Generate code from   | Generate code from JSON manifest |
|   | Validate JSON manifest before generating |
|   | Open ERD diagram in browser |

See [JSON Manifest](/docs/json-manifest) for the AI-optimized workflow using a single JSON file.

## Project Structure

After initialization, your project will have:

 
my-app/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ archetype.config.ts          # Main configuration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ archetype/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ entities/
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ task.ts              # Example entity
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ generated/                   # Auto-generated (don't edit)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ db/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ schema.ts            # Drizzle schema
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ schemas/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ task.ts              # Zod validation
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ trpc/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ routers/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ task.ts          # tRPC router
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ index.ts         # Combined router
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ hooks/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ useTask.ts           # React hooks
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tests/                   # üÜï Auto-generated tests
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ task.test.ts         # Test suites
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ setup.ts             # Test config
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/                    # üÜï Auto-generated API docs
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ openapi.json         # OpenAPI 3.0 spec
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ swagger.html         # Swagger UI
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ API.md               # Markdown docs
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ seeds/                   # üÜï Auto-generated seed data
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ task.ts              # Seed functions
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.ts             # Orchestrator
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ run.ts               # CLI runner
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ erd.md                   # Mermaid diagram
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ server/
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ db.ts                # Database connection
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ trpc.ts              # tRPC setup
 

## Configuration

The   file is your main configuration:

 typescript
import { defineConfig } from 'archetype-engine'
import { Task } from './archetype/entities/task'

export default defineConfig({
  entities: [Task],
  database: {
    type: 'sqlite',
    file: './sqlite.db',
  },
})
 

### Database Options

 typescript
// SQLite
database: { type: 'sqlite', file: './sqlite.db' }

// PostgreSQL
database: { type: 'postgres', url: process.env.DATABASE_URL }

// Turso
database: { type: 'turso', url: process.env.TURSO_URL, authToken: process.env.TURSO_TOKEN }
 bash Create Next project create next Install archetype install archetype engine Initialize creates config entities infrastructure archetype init Generate code archetype generate Push database schema drizzle push bash install archetype engine archetype init archetype generate bash archetype engine directory build link your project link archetype engine archetype init archetype generate archetype config Main configuration archetype entities task Example entity generated Auto generated edit schema Drizzle schema schemas task validation trpc routers task tRPC router index Combined router hooks useTask React hooks tests Auto generated tests task test Test suites setup Test config docs Auto generated docs openapi json OpenAPI spec swagger html Swagger Markdown docs seeds Auto generated seed data task Seed functions index Orchestrator runner Mermaid diagram server Database connection trpc tRPC setup typescript import defineConfig from archetype engine import Task from archetype entities task export default defineConfig entities Task database type sqlite file sqlite typescript SQLite database type sqlite file sqlite PostgreSQL database type postgres process Turso database type turso process authToken process
6.headings: Getting Started Prerequisites Installation Option 1: New Project Create Next.js project Install archetype Initialize (creates config + entities + infrastructure) Generate code Push database schema and run Option 2: Existing Project Option 3: Local Development (npm link) In archetype-engine directory In your project CLI Commands Project Structure Configuration Database Options Next Steps

7.title: Generated
7.description: Archetype generates comprehensive, production-ready code from your entity definitions.
7.content:
# Generated Code Archetype generates comprehensive, production-ready code from your entity definitions. ## What Gets Generated From a single entity definition, you get 1,400+ lines of production code: ## Database Schemas Location: Type-safe Drizzle ORM tables with: - Column definitions matching your field types - Foreign key constraints for relations - Indexes for unique fields - Timestamps (if enabled) - Soft delete columns (if enabled) ## Validation Schemas Location: Zod schemas for runtime validation: Features: - Maps field types to Zod validators (, , etc.) - Applies all validation rules (min, max, email, url, regex) - Excludes computed fields from create/update schemas - Supports i18n error messages when multiple languages configured - Exports TypeScript types for use in your code ## API Routers Location: Full CRUD tRPC procedures: Features: - Authentication checks (uses when entity is protected) - Soft delete support (sets instead of DELETE) - Computed fields added to responses - Lifecycle hooks invoked (if enabled) - Filtering with multiple operators (eq, ne, gt, lt, contains, etc.) - Full-text search across all text fields ## React Hooks Location: React Query hooks for data fetching: - - List with filters - - Single record - - Create mutation - - Update mutation - - Delete mutation ## Tests (New!) Location: Comprehensive Vitest test suites covering: - CRUD operations - Validation (required fields, email format, min/max) - Authentication (protected operations) - Filtering, search, pagination - Batch operations - Soft delete, timestamps Usage: ## API Documentation (New!) Location: Complete API documentation: - OpenAPI 3.0 spec () - Machine-readable API definition - Swagger UI () - Interactive API explorer - Markdown docs () - Human-readable documentation Usage: ## Seed Data (New!) Location: Realistic sample data for development: - Smart field mapping (emails get emails, names get person names) - Respects validation constraints - Handles entity dependencies - Optional faker.js integration Usage: ## Regeneration When you update entities: All files are regenerated. Never edit generated files directly - use hooks for custom logic. ## Stats For typical setup (User + Post entities): | Component | Lines Generated | |-----------|----------------| | Database schemas | 150 | | Validation | 100 | | API routers | 600 | | React hooks | 300 | | Tests | 434 | | API docs | 1,097 | | Seed data | 151 | | Total | 2,832 lines | From 40 lines of entity definitions. Ratio: 71:1 (71 lines generated per 1 written) 
generated/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ db/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ schema.ts              # Drizzle ORM tables
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ schemas/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {entity}.ts            # Zod validation schemas
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ trpc/routers/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ {entity}.ts            # tRPC CRUD routers
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ index.ts               # Combined app router
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ hooks/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ use{Entity}.ts         # React Query hooks
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tests/                     # üÜï Auto-generated tests
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ {entity}.test.ts       # Comprehensive test suites
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ setup.ts               # Test configuration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/                      # üÜï Auto-generated API docs
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ openapi.json           # OpenAPI 3.0 specification
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ swagger.html           # Interactive Swagger UI
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ API.md                 # Markdown documentation
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ seeds/                     # üÜï Auto-generated seed data
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ {entity}.ts            # Seed functions per entity
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.ts               # Orchestrator
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ run.ts                 # CLI runner
 

## Database Schemas

**Location:**  

Type-safe Drizzle ORM tables with:
- Column definitions matching your field types
- Foreign key constraints for relations
- Indexes for unique fields
- Timestamps (if enabled)
- Soft delete columns (if enabled)

## Validation Schemas

**Location:**  

Zod schemas for runtime validation:

 typescript
// generated/schemas/product.ts
import { z } from 'zod'

export const productCreateSchema = z.object({
  name: z.string().min(1, 'Name is required').max(200),
  price: z.number().positive('Price must be positive'),
  stock: z.number().int().min(0).default(0),
})

export const productUpdateSchema = z.object({
  id: z.string(),
  data: productCreateSchema.partial(),
})

export type ProductCreateInput = z.infer<typeof productCreateSchema>
export type ProductUpdateInput = z.infer<typeof productUpdateSchema>
 

**Features:**
- Maps field types to Zod validators ( , etc.)
- Applies all validation rules (min, max, email, url, regex)
- Excludes computed fields from create/update schemas
- Supports i18n error messages when multiple languages configured
- Exports TypeScript types for use in your code

## API Routers

**Location:**  

Full CRUD tRPC procedures:

 typescript
// generated/trpc/routers/product.ts
import { router, publicProcedure } from '../trpc'
import { productCreateSchema, productUpdateSchema } from '../../schemas/product'

export const productRouter = router({
  // List with pagination, filtering, search
  list: publicProcedure
    .input(z.object({
      page: z.number().default(1),
      limit: z.number().default(20),
      where: z.record(z.any()).optional(),
      search: z.string().optional(),
      orderBy: z.object({
        field: z.string(),
        direction: z.enum(['asc', 'desc']),
      }).optional(),
    }))
    .query(async ({ input }) => {
      // Returns: { items, total, page, limit, hasMore }
    }),

  // Get single record
  get: publicProcedure
    .input(z.string())
    .query(async ({ input: id }) => {
      // Returns single record or throws
    }),

  // Create
  create: publicProcedure
    .input(productCreateSchema)
    .mutation(async ({ input }) => {
      // Returns created record
    }),

  // Batch create
  createMany: publicProcedure
    .input(z.object({ items: z.array(productCreateSchema).max(100) }))
    .mutation(async ({ input }) => {
      // Returns { created: Product[], count: number }
    }),

  // Update
  update: publicProcedure
    .input(productUpdateSchema)
    .mutation(async ({ input }) => {
      // Returns updated record
    }),

  // Batch update
  updateMany: publicProcedure
    .input(z.object({
      items: z.array(z.object({
        id: z.string(),
        data: productCreateSchema.partial(),
      })).max(100),
    }))
    .mutation(async ({ input }) => {
      // Returns { updated: Product[], count: number }
    }),

  // Remove
  remove: publicProcedure
    .input(z.string())
    .mutation(async ({ input: id }) => {
      // Soft delete if enabled, hard delete otherwise
    }),

  // Batch remove
  removeMany: publicProcedure
    .input(z.object({ ids: z.array(z.string()).max(100) }))
    .mutation(async ({ input }) => {
      // Returns { removed: Product[], count: number }
    }),
})
 

**Features:**
- Authentication checks (uses   when entity is protected)
- Soft delete support (sets   instead of DELETE)
- Computed fields added to responses
- Lifecycle hooks invoked (if enabled)
- Filtering with multiple operators (eq, ne, gt, lt, contains, etc.)
- Full-text search across all text fields

## React Hooks

**Location:**  

React Query hooks for data fetching:
-   - List with filters
-   - Single record
-   - Create mutation
-   - Update mutation
-   - Delete mutation

## Tests (New!)

**Location:**  

Comprehensive Vitest test suites covering:
- CRUD operations
- Validation (required fields, email format, min/max)
- Authentication (protected operations)
- Filtering, search, pagination
- Batch operations
- Soft delete, timestamps

**Usage:**
 bash
npm test
 

## API Documentation (New!)

**Location:**  

Complete API documentation:
- **OpenAPI 3.0 spec** ( ) - Machine-readable API definition
- **Swagger UI** ( ) - Interactive API explorer
- **Markdown docs** ( ) - Human-readable documentation

**Usage:**
 bash
# Open Swagger UI in browser
open generated/docs/swagger.html
 

## Seed Data (New!)

**Location:**  

Realistic sample data for development:
- Smart field mapping (emails get emails, names get person names)
- Respects validation constraints
- Handles entity dependencies
- Optional faker.js integration

**Usage:**
 bash
npm run seed         # Seed database
npm run seed --reset # Reset + seed
 

## Regeneration

When you update entities:
 bash
npx archetype generate
 generated schema Drizzle tables schemas entity validation schemas trpc routers entity tRPC CRUD routers index Combined router hooks Entity React Query hooks tests Auto generated tests entity test Comprehensive test suites setup Test configuration docs Auto generated docs openapi json OpenAPI specification swagger html Interactive Swagger Markdown documentation seeds Auto generated seed data entity Seed functions entity index Orchestrator runner typescript generated schemas product import from export const productCreateSchema object name string Name required price number positive Price must positive stock number default export const productUpdateSchema object string data productCreateSchema partial export type ProductCreateInput infer typeof productCreateSchema export type ProductUpdateInput infer typeof productUpdateSchema typescript generated trpc routers product import router publicProcedure from trpc import productCreateSchema productUpdateSchema from schemas product export const productRouter router List with pagination filtering search list publicProcedure input object page number default limit number default where record optional search string optional orderBy object field string direction enum desc optional query async input Returns items total page limit hasMore single record publicProcedure input string query async input Returns single record throws Create create publicProcedure input productCreateSchema mutation async input Returns created record Batch create createMany publicProcedure input object items array productCreateSchema mutation async input Returns created Product count number Update update publicProcedure input productUpdateSchema mutation async input Returns updated record Batch update updateMany publicProcedure input object items array object string data productCreateSchema partial mutation async input Returns updated Product count number Remove remove publicProcedure input string mutation async input Soft delete enabled hard delete otherwise Batch remove removeMany publicProcedure input object array string mutation async input Returns removed Product count number bash test bash Open Swagger browser open generated docs swagger html bash seed Seed database seed reset Reset seed bash archetype generate

8.title: Filtering
8.headings: Filtering & Search Basic Usage Pagination Filtering with where Simple Equality Text Operators Number/Date Operators Boolean Multiple Conditions Full-Text Search Sorting Complete Example tRPC Direct Usage

9.title: Fields
9.description: Fields define the properties of your entities. Archetype provides four primary field types with a fluent API for validation and constraints.
9.content:
# Fields Fields define the properties of your entities. Archetype provides four primary field types with a fluent API for validation and constraints. ## Field Types ### text() String fields with optional validation: ### number() Numeric fields: ### boolean() Boolean fields: ### date() Date/timestamp fields: ## Common Methods All field types support these methods: | Method | Description | |--------|-------------| | | Field must have a value | | | Field can be null/undefined | | | Value must be unique in table | | | Default value if not provided | | | Human-readable label for UI/errors | ## Text-Specific Methods | Method | Description | |--------|-------------| | | Must be valid email format | | | Must be valid URL | | | Must match regex pattern | | | Must be one of the provided values | | | Trim whitespace | | | Convert to lowercase | | | Convert to uppercase | | | Minimum length | | | Maximum length | | | Alias for | ## Number-Specific Methods | Method | Description | |--------|-------------| | | Must be a whole number | | | Must be greater than 0 | | | Minimum value | | | Maximum value | ## Date-Specific Methods | Method | Description | |--------|-------------| | | Default to current timestamp | ## Examples ### User Profile ### Product ## Generated Validation Fields generate Zod schemas automatically: typescript
import { text } from 'archetype-engine'

// Basic text field
name: text().required()

// With validations
email: text().required().email()
website: text().optional().url()
slug: text().required().regex(/^[a-z0-9-]+$/)
role: text().required().oneOf(['admin', 'user', 'guest'])

// With transformations
username: text().required().trim().lowercase()
code: text().required().uppercase()

// With length constraints
bio: text().optional().min(10).max(500)
title: text().required().length(100)  // max length
 

### number()

Numeric fields:

 typescript
import { number } from 'archetype-engine'

// Basic number
quantity: number().required()

// With constraints
age: number().required().integer().min(0).max(120)
price: number().required().positive()
rating: number().optional().min(1).max(5)
 

### boolean()

Boolean fields:

 typescript
import { boolean } from 'archetype-engine'

isActive: boolean().default(true)
isVerified: boolean().default(false)
acceptedTerms: boolean().required()
 

### date()

Date/timestamp fields:

 typescript
import { date } from 'archetype-engine'

birthDate: date().required()
publishedAt: date().optional()
expiresAt: date().default('now')  // current timestamp
 

## Common Methods

All field types support these methods:

| Method | Description |
|--------|-------------|
|   | Field must have a value |
|   | Field can be null/undefined |
|   | Value must be unique in table |
|   | Default value if not provided |
|   | Human-readable label for UI/errors |

## Text-Specific Methods

| Method | Description |
|--------|-------------|
|   | Must be valid email format |
|   | Must be valid URL |
|   | Must match regex pattern |
|   | Must be one of the provided values |
|   | Trim whitespace |
|   | Convert to lowercase |
|   | Convert to uppercase |
|   | Minimum length |
|   | Maximum length |
|   | Alias for   |

## Number-Specific Methods

| Method | Description |
|--------|-------------|
|   | Must be a whole number |
|   | Must be greater than 0 |
|   | Minimum value |
|   | Maximum value |

## Date-Specific Methods

| Method | Description |
|--------|-------------|
|   | Default to current timestamp |

## Examples

### User Profile

 typescript
export const User = defineEntity('User', {
  fields: {
    email: text().required().unique().email(),
    username: text().required().unique().min(3).max(20).lowercase().trim(),
    displayName: text().required().min(1).max(50),
    bio: text().optional().max(500),
    age: number().optional().integer().min(13).max(120),
    isVerified: boolean().default(false),
    lastLoginAt: date().optional(),
    createdAt: date().default('now'),
  },
})
 

### Product

 typescript
export const Product = defineEntity('Product', {
  fields: {
    sku: text().required().unique().uppercase(),
    name: text().required().min(1).max(200),
    description: text().optional(),
    price: number().required().positive(),
    compareAtPrice: number().optional().positive(),
    quantity: number().required().integer().min(0),
    isActive: boolean().default(true),
    publishedAt: date().optional(),
  },
})
 

## Generated Validation

Fields generate Zod schemas automatically:

 typescript
// Input definition
email: text().required().email()
age: number().optional().integer().min(0)

// Generated Zod schema
z.object({
  email: z.string().email(),
  age: z.number().int().min(0).optional(),
})
 typescript import text from archetype engine Basic text field name text required With validations email text required email website text optional slug text required regex role text required oneOf admin user guest With transformations username text required trim lowercase code text required uppercase With length constraints text optional title text required length length typescript import number from archetype engine Basic number quantity number required With constraints number required integer price number required positive rating number optional typescript import boolean from archetype engine isActive boolean default true isVerified boolean default false acceptedTerms boolean required typescript import date from archetype engine birthDate date required publishedAt date optional expiresAt date default current timestamp typescript export const User defineEntity User fields email text required unique email username text required unique lowercase trim displayName text required text optional number optional integer isVerified boolean default false lastLoginAt date optional createdAt date default typescript export const Product defineEntity Product fields text required unique uppercase name text required description text optional price number required positive compareAtPrice number optional positive quantity number required integer isActive boolean default true publishedAt date optional typescript Input definition email text required email number optional integer Generated schema object email string email number optional
9.headings: Fields Field Types text() number() boolean() date() Common Methods Text-Specific Methods Number-Specific Methods Date-Specific Methods Examples User Profile Product Generated Validation

10.title: External
10.headings: External Sources (Headless Mode) Quick Example Basic Setup 1. Define External Source 2. 11.title: Enum
11.description: Define constrained string fields that only accept specific values. Generates native PostgreSQL enums or validated text columns for SQLite.
11.headings: Enum Fields Definition Methods Generated Code PostgreSQL SQLite Examples Order Status Priority Levels User Roles Payment Status Enum vs text().oneOf() Type Safety

12.title: Entities
12.description: Entities are the core building blocks of Archetype. Each entity represents a data model that generates database tables, API endpoints, and React hooks.
12.headings: Entities Defining an Entity Entity Options Complete Example What Gets Generated Database Schema Zod Validation tRPC Router React Hooks Naming Conventions

13.title: Computed
13.description: Computed fields are derived from other fields at runtime. They're not stored in the database but included in all API responses.
13.headings: Computed Fields Definition Options Examples Full Name Order Total Status Label Age from Birth Date Generated Code Schema Validation Router Usage Limitations

14.title: Behaviors
14.description: Behaviors are built-in patterns that add common functionality to entities. Enable them in the option. behaviors
14.headings: Behaviors Available Behaviors timestamps softDelete Combining Behaviors Example Usage With Timestamps With Soft Delete Future Behaviors

15.title: Batch
15.description: Perform bulk create, update, and delete operations efficiently.
15.headings: Batch Operations Available Operations createMany Input Format Response updateMany Input Format Response removeMany Input Format Response Examples Import from CSV Bulk Price Update Delete Selected Limits

16.title: Authentication
16.description: Archetype integrates with NextAuth.js (Auth.js) v5 to provide authentication out of the box.
16.content:
# Authentication Archetype integrates with NextAuth.js (Auth.js) v5 to provide authentication out of the box. ## Enabling Auth Add the option to your config: ## Available Providers | Provider | Description | |----------|-------------| | | Email/password login | | | Google OAuth | | | GitHub OAuth | | | Discord OAuth | ## Init Flow When running , you'll be prompted: ## Generated Files After running with auth enabled: ### auth.ts ### Auth Schema ## Environment Variables Add to : Generate a secret: ## Using Auth in Your App ### Get Current Session ### Sign In/Out ## Protected Entities Once auth is enabled, you can protect entity operations. See Protection for details. auth typescript // archetype.config.ts import { defineConfig } from 'archetype-engine' export default defineConfig({ entities: [...], database: { type: 'sqlite', file: './sqlite.db' }, auth: { enabled: true, providers: ['credentials', 'google', 'github'], sessionStrategy: 'jwt', // or 'database' }, }) ## Available Providers | Provider | Description | |----------|-------------| | | Email/password login | | | Google OAuth | | | GitHub OAuth | | | Discord OAuth | ## Init Flow When running , you'll be prompted: ? Enable authentication? (y/N) y ? Select auth providers: ‚óâ Credentials (email/password) ‚óØ Google ‚óØ GitHub ‚óØ Discord ## Generated Files After running with auth enabled: src/ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ server/ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ auth.ts # NextAuth configuration ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ app/ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ api/ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ auth/ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ [...nextauth]/ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ route.ts # Auth API routes generated/ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ db/ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ auth-schema.ts # Auth tables (users, accounts, sessions) ### auth.ts typescript import NextAuth from 'next-auth' import Credentials from 'next-auth/providers/credentials' import Google from 'next-auth/providers/google' import { DrizzleAdapter } from '@auth/drizzle-adapter' import { db } from './db' export const { handlers, auth, signIn, signOut } = NextAuth({ adapter: DrizzleAdapter(db), providers: [ Credentials({ credentials: { email: { label: 'Email', type: 'email' }, password: { label: 'Password', type: 'password' }, }, authorize: async (credentials) => { // Implement your credential validation return null }, }), Google({ clientId: process.env.GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID, clientSecret: process.env.GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET, }), ], session: { strategy: 'jwt' }, }) ### Auth Schema typescript // generated/db/auth-schema.ts export const users = sqliteTable('users', { id: text('id').primaryKey(), name: text('name'), email: text('email').unique(), emailVerified: integer('email_verified'), image: text('image'), }) export const accounts = sqliteTable('accounts', { ... }) export const sessions = sqliteTable('sessions', { ... }) export const verificationTokens = sqliteTable('verification_tokens', { ... }) ## Environment Variables Add to bash # Required AUTH_SECRET="generate-a-secret-here" # For Google provider GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID="..." GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET="..." # For GitHub provider GITHUB_CLIENT_ID="..." GITHUB_CLIENT_SECRET="..." Generate a secret: bash npx auth secret ## Using Auth in Your App ### Get Current Session typescript import { auth } from '@/server/auth' export default async function Page() { const session = await auth() if (!session) { return

Not logged in

} return

Hello, {session.user.name}

} ### Sign In/Out typescript import { signIn, signOut } from '@/server/auth' // Server action async function handleSignIn() { 'use server' await signIn('google') } async function handleSignOut() { 'use server' await signOut() } typescript archetype config import defineConfig from archetype engine export default defineConfig entities database type sqlite file sqlite auth enabled true providers credentials google github sessionStrategy database Enable authentication Select auth providers Credentials email password Google GitHub Discord server auth NextAuth configuration auth nextauth route Auth routes generated auth schema Auth tables users accounts sessions typescript import NextAuth from next auth import Credentials from next auth providers credentials import Google from next auth providers google import DrizzleAdapter from auth drizzle adapter import from export const handlers auth signIn signOut NextAuth adapter DrizzleAdapter providers Credentials credentials email label Email type email password label Password type password authorize async credentials Implement your credential validation return null Google clientId process clientSecret process session strategy typescript generated auth schema export const users sqliteTable users text primaryKey name text name email text email unique emailVerified integer image text image export const accounts sqliteTable accounts export const sessions sqliteTable sessions export const verificationTokens sqliteTable bash Required generate secret here Google provider GitHub provider bash auth secret typescript import auth from server auth export default async function Page const session await auth session return logged return Hello session user name typescript import signIn signOut from server auth Server action async function handleSignIn server await signIn google async function handleSignOut server await signOut
16.headings: Authentication Enabling Auth Available Providers Init Flow Generated Files auth.ts Auth Schema Environment Variables Required For Google provider For GitHub provider Using Auth in Your App Get Current Session Sign In/Out Protected Entities
